messageBody:
Mike,
    I think reason Matt thought new asserts would be a good idea is the automatic error messages you get.  With assertEquals it not only tells you that the test failed, but also the actual and expected values that caused the test to fail. 
 
Using functors does not add this extra value.
 
Dave
-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
Sent: 22 May 2001 19:41
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] creating more assertX methods

--- Matt Munz <matt@...> wrote:
> Hi all,
>
>     I've been using assertEquals (Junit v3.5) in many tests and it
> works well.  I've been thinking that it might be handy to have
> assertGreater() and assertGreaterOrEqual() methods as well.  My first
> impulse is to subclass Assert and put them there.  Is there another
> (better) way to do this? Any ideas would be appreciated.  If anyone
> has done this before and would like to send me their code, that would
> be appreciated too ;)
>

Just a thought...

Rather than using inheritance, you could define binary methods
(functors) that are then used by the canonical assertion methods of the
Assert class, as in

    public class AssertRange {
        public static boolean greaterThanOrEqual(int a, int b) {
            return a >= b;
        }
        public static boolean lessThanOrEqual(int a, int b) {
            return a <= b;
        }
    }

    public void testSomething() {
        assert("Test something",
            AssertRange.greaterThanOrEquals(9, 10));
    }

This may help promote pluggability of assertion behavior.

The other option would be to use composition rather than inheritance.
The AssertRange could delegate to the Assert class.

Mike
